properties.Name: BondYieldToMaturity
properties.Description:
The price of a bond is the sum of the present values of all expected coupon payments plus the present value of the par value at maturity, which equals all interest received + gains or losses.

The rate of return anticipated on a bond if it is held until the maturity date.

 YTM is considered a long-term bond yield expressed as an annual rate. 

The calculation of YTM takes into account the current market price, par value, coupon interest rate and time to maturity. It is also assumed that all coupons are reinvested at the same rate.

Yield To Maturity provides the total return you will receive by holding the bond until it matures or is called.

Note:
Yield to maturity and yield to call take into account the value of the discount or premium paid for the bond, and as such they offer a much better indication of the value of the bond. 

Ex:
The yield-to-maturity is the best measure of the return rate because it includes all aspects of your investment.  

Add up these present values, the sum will equal your initial investment. 

A representative equation is:

1. c(1 + r)-1 + c(1 + r)-2 + . . + c(1 + r)-n + B(1 + r)-n = P  
    where 
 c = annual coupon payment $
 n = number of years to maturity 
 B = par value 
 P = purchase price 

The sum of all the present values will exactly equal the purchase price of the bond.

Example:   Suppose your bond is selling for $950, and has a coupon rate of 7%; it matures in 4 years, and the par value is $1000. 

The coupon payment is $70 (that's 7% of $1000), so the equation to satisfy is 

2. 70(1 + r)-1 + 70(1 + r)-2 + 70(1 + r)-3 + 70(1 + r)-4 + 1000(1 + r)-4 = 950  

r is 8.53%.

Columns.Name: BondId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of a Financial Product.

Columns.Name: Date
Columns.Description: The date as of which the associated bond pricing is calculated.
